Award.AwardTitle: GOALI: Developing Uncooled Microbolometer Arrays Based on Thin Films of Hole Doped Rare Earth Perovskite Manganite Materials

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The proposed work is a collaborative effort between Towson University and the industrial partner Triton Services Inc. towards developing uncooled microbolometer arrays based on thin films of hole-doped rare earth perovskite manganite materials. Epitaxial manganite thin films will be developed on Silicon, employing lattice engineering schemes, and the properties of these films will be optimized for bolometer operation at or close to room temperature. Single test bolometers and microbolometer arrays will be fabricated and device performance will be evaluated.
Intellectual merit: Manganite materials hold potential for superior performance in terms of sensitivity, stability and robustness compared to other bolometer materials currently employed for uncooled IR imaging. Successful demonstration and evaluation of manganite microbolometer arrays will lead to the assimilation of this technology by the IR imaging industry. The proposed effort will generate a knowledge base related to materials manipulation, silicon-integration and device fabrication, which will be useful for other technological applications of the manganites. The materials physics involved in the hetero-epitaxial lattice engineering will contribute to the understanding of oxide hetero-structures and interfaces.
Broader Impacts: the proposed effort will enhance the educational experience of the students at Towson University through the industry-university interaction. Graduate students of the recently started professional science masters program will be involved in the proposed work. The industry-university collaboration and student involvement in applied research will serve as a model for other professional science masters programs. Content related to the proposed project will also be incorporated in K-12 STEM outreach activities at Towson University.

Research Goals and Outcomes

The goal of this GOALI (Grant Opportunities for Academic Liaison with Industry)  project was to develop materials suitable for imaging using infrared radiation which is employed in night vision devices. Since materials currently being used have several drawbacks, there is a need for new materials whose properties can approach or surpass the capabilities of current materials but without their drawbacks. Optimization of the material composition for operation close to ambient temperature, growing the materials on Silicon for integration with imaging electronics, estimation of sensor performance parameters and fabrication of prototype arrays are the main tasks to be completed towards such a goal. At the end of the project period, we had identified suitable candidate materials and developed thin films of these materials on silicon. We demonstrated performance characteristics that make these materials competent with currently used materials such as vanadium oxide. We have identified a material composition with  a temperature-coefficient-of-resistance  of ~6.5%/K at ~285 K and ~4.5 % at ~292 K  which is superior to the properties of Vanadium Oxide.  Due to an unforeseen change in the project leadership in the later stage of the award (related to organizational change of our industrial partner), we had to revise the project goals, which was done with the consent of our program officers at NSF. The new direction was focused on developing nanolithography techniques using an atomic force microscope to develop nanoscale features on the surface of electronically active sensor materials, closely related to the materials we had developed earlier for infrared imaging. This work lead to the first successful  experimental analysis the chemical changes involved in atomic force microscope-induced surface modifications. We were also successful in developing  a conceptual framework  for the chemical reactions involved in such surface modification. Our results are expected to pave the way for the use of AFM nanolithography to design material surfaces for applications such as catalysis, which is necessary for ‘water-splitting’ whereby solar energy can be used to generate hydrogen from water. Our research resulted in three peer reviewed publications and 14 conference presentations at the annual March meetings of the American Physical Society.

Impact on Research and Human Resource Development

 This grant has had a profound impact on human resources through educational and research experiences imparted to graduate (master’s) and undergraduate students.  Overall, four master’s students and five undergraduate students participated in this project at various stages. The publications from this grant had three master’s student and one undergraduate student as co-authors. Both graduate and undergraduate students presented their work at conferences which gave them networking opportunities for future career development.  Students have acquired state of the art laboratory skills in materials as well as research skills such as critical thinking, data analysis, information gathering, problem solving and team work.  Student participants in this project have obtained job placements and internships related to science and engineering, linked to the skills they have acquired. These students have informed the PI that the research experience in their resumes, and the skills they have acquired were instrumental in their success.
